title: 107_hr1621
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001" and includes findings and purposes. The Arabia Mountain area contains diverse natural, cultural, and historical resources that are worthy of recognition and conservation. Partnerships between public and private entities are the best way to manage these resources. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve and Panola Mountain are key sites within the area. The Panola Mountain State Conservation Park features a pristine granite outcrop, while the Miners Creek Preserve contains evidence of early human activity. The city of Lithonia, Georgia, along with Arabia Mountain and Stone Mountain, showcase the history of granite mining in the region. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation, and Lithonia has 2 structures listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote the natural, cultural, and historical resources in the area, including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites and communities in Georgia. The Act aims to develop and implement a cultural, historical, and land resource management program to protect and interpret significant resources within the heritage area that includes Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other sites in Georgia. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. This section establishes the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia. Establishment of Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. Map available for public inspection. Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance designated as management entity. Authorities and duties of the management entity outlined. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests and gives priority to preserving resources within the heritage area. The management entity for Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is responsible for implementing actions in the management plan, including assisting government and nonprofit organizations, encouraging land use policies, conducting quarterly public meetings, submitting annual reports on accomplishments and finances, and allowing audits of Federal fund expenditures. The management entity must provide all records for audit to the Secretary regarding the expenditure of Federal funds and ensure receiving organizations do the same. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real property, but funds from other sources can be used for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept in the feasibility study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, agencies, and organizations, and include an inventory of resources to be preserved, restored, managed, or maintained. The management plan for the heritage area includes an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, implementation program, and evaluation of the management entity. The management plan for the heritage area must include an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, implementation program, and evaluation of the management entity. The plan should also identify funding sources and be submitted to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of enactment. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of submission. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding under the Act. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan within 90 days of submission. If disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and allow for revisions. Any revisions must be approved or disapproved within 90 days of submission. After the Secretary approves a management plan, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for any revisions to the plan. No funds can be used to implement a revision until it is approved by the Secretary. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE: The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. 

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: $10,000,000 is authorized for this Act, with a maximum of $1,000,000 per fiscal year, and the Federal share of project costs not exceeding 50 percent.

SEC. 9. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY: Details the termination of authority under the Act. The Secretary can provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for implementing the management plan. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Act, with a maximum of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The authority to make grants or provide assistance under this Act ends on September 30, 2016.
